reviewText:
This was a great game when released, but now it's showing its age. It's satisfyingly challenging, especially on the higher difficulty settings.

It's fun laying out your railway and you get a good sense of getting better at the game the more you play it, as you get involved with the more advanced functions, such as personal wealth and the stock market. The differing goals on each level, the changing emphasis depending on the year and the big shift between difficulty levels are easily enough to hold your interest over the long-term. While there's some luck involved, particularly with the economy, success is mostly a case of skill and planning. The economic model is good enough, if not spectacular.

On the downside, the user interface looks and feels like it was designed in 1998 (as it was). It can be hard finding some of the more important functions (or even the existence of them in some cases). I would recommend at least scanning through the manual.

The graphics are perfectly functional - as an isometric rather than a 3D game, they've aged better than most of this vintage. The intra-level cutscenes set the scene for the level quite well. I enjoyed the bluegrass music, even though I'm not a fan of the genre - it fits the pace of the game exactly.

As in common with many games in this genre, there's a tipping point" at each level where you're sure that you'll be successful. The game has ten speed levels and this comes in very handy at that point.

If you're having trouble deciding
date: "Railroad Tycoon 3" is definitely the better game
recommended: particularly the economic model and user interface. However this can be difficult to get running on modern systems. "Railroads!" is almost a different kind of game
hoursPlayed: much easier and less in-depth - I didn't like it.\n\nIf you like management sims
voteText: you should get a lot of enjoyment out of this
helpfulPercent: particularly as it's so cheap. If you're not sure
votesHelpful: or haven't played that style of game much
votesTotal: you'll probably be better off buying something more modern."

reviewText:
Railroad Tycoon 2 is in my opinion the best railroad company simulator there ever was.
It is reasonable in difficulty, graphics did not age too terribly and while it is simplified a bit, the corelations between products and different buildings spawning on the map through time give it endless replayability.

reviewText: This game is kickass!  It engages your brain - memory and planning are paramount - while also having an excellent American folk soundtrack of guitars and harmonicas.  Daft numbers of scenarios & campaigns, all with inherent replayability, can be boosted to astronomical proportions (https://codeload.github.com/oseparovic/RRT2Maps/zip/master << that's a metric f*ck-tonne of extra maps & scenarios).  I have a thing for older games - they tended to be more demanding and more mentally stimulating than modern games - and this fully lives up to those ideals.\n\nThe game consists of competing with AI or human-controlled opponents (or not, if that's what you want) to connect trade resources on a map, against the backdrop of a potentially lethal economy and advancing technology.  The right scenarios (in the zip I linked to above) will let you go for >150 years - some are even without a time limit - but you typically are presented goals - specific things to achieve by a specific time, in order to get a bronze, silver or gold medal (these goals are usually along the lines of Connect point x to point y
date: move twelvety tonnes of cargo K between those two points and amass $------ personal fortune by date z").\n\nI give you fair warning
recommended: the graphics aren't going to blow you away
helpfulPercent: detail and the intense addictiveness of the game should tickle you if you're prone to being tickled by a game of this type."

reviewText:
If you are an analytical, logistics-oriented person who can coalesce money and talent around you to achieve ambitious goals, please submit your application to Railroad Tycoon 2 platinum.

I played this game when it first came out, it's still as solid a title now as it was then, and the mechanics and controls have aged well. While some of the campaign can be quite merciless, I hardly see how that's a problem (considering today's trends towards easy instant satisfaction games).

The AI on the map can leave something to be desired. They build weird routes, and often never expand beyond their two city connections for many years. However, what they lack in physical construction prowess they make up for with their brutal manipulation of the in-game stock market. Which is a peeve, because the market can be very hard to keep up on while you're trying to build a route through rugged mountain terrain, only to find that the dickhole AI has bought out your company, repossessed all of your assets that you put up to start said company, and then locked you out of your office so they can take a big dump on your desk.

But I digress. For the price of the game on the Steam marketplace, you will get a solid return on your investment. hours of fun. Hours of mind numbing track laying, split-screening market trading, and maxing out your profit by alternatively trimming routes and tuning the makeup of the various trains that ply them.

reviewText: Ahh, Railroad Tycoon II. Another game resurrected from the mists of time and childhood memories of playing this game as a starry-eyed child with my train-obsessed father. Once the shine of nostalgia had worn away a little, however, I found myself able to give a more..objective review of the game. The positives? Well, the music is great, the attention to detail (particularly with the trains and historical aspects) is pretty impressive, and the gameplay, at its core, is quite addictive. As you play, you find yourself eager to expand your railway, to explore the map and find out what locomotive will be unlocked next. There's also an impressive array of scenarios/maps to play, and an amusing level editor. However, one drawback I found is that the game can be rather confusing. There are no proper tutorials, none that I could find anyway (occasional hint boxes hardly count), and it's scarily easy to run out of money, which in turn annoys your investors and nets you a game over. The interface can be rather confusing, and at the risk of sounding stupid, I don't really understand the financial side of the game (bonds and stock, etc) and how that all works. All that being said though, if you can wrap your head around the confusing mechanics, this is still a timeless classic of a game, and very enjoyable. Not the best, but definitely recommended as a cheap time-waster.

reviewText:
An old classic, filled with nostalgia and train steam. The game ranges from simple difficulties where you just relax, transport goods around and build new tracks, to full fledged industry operations where every dollar must be spent wisely, you can compete with the AI or other players at both the train stations and the financial markets, and the goods must be delivered from and to specific locations to get enough profit out of it.

On the wrong side, the UI  would have needed way more tooltips, and the game is generally obscure in what does what and why.

Overall, a good choice if you like trains and that old game vibe.

reviewText:
I have played this game from the CD for many hours, just bought Steam version. You may trust my review.
This ain't yo mamma's kind of game. No this ain't. Railroad Tycoon 2, in my opinion the best of all train games new or old, is one that'll make you frustrated by all means whilst keeping you up till all hours of the night. Let me explain why.

The rail building is not easy. You must pick your terrain carefully and stategically. Mountains will cost you more, and slow your trains down. Plains are cheaper and don't require heavy-duty 3-Truck Shay trains. Deciding which cities to connect together via a rail also takes thought. The larger the city, the more passenger and mail revenue is to be had. The maps in this game are realistically made (Alaska map looks like Alaska).

But when you do finally get your rail system figured out, it's time to turn to the Stock Market. Very useful in making lots of personal cash, issuing stock for some extra company cash, or merging with another rail company. Invest wisely, the AI in this game were created intelligently. For example if you see Jay Gould in your game (look him up:) watch your back, while other tycoons may not even utilize the Market at all. Every tycoon Character in this game has a different personality.

So in conclusion, this game is 17+ years old and out of every rail game out right now, I still choose to play ol' RRT2. Yes max res is 1024 x 768, maybe an HD version would pop up someday? This game takes time to learn, but once down you will definently need a better office chair and a comfortable mouse pad. Also there are websites out to download user created maps/scenarios, and a map editor to create your own (this comes with game). Much replayability.

reviewText:
Fantastic, underappreciated game
This is the best of the 3 in the series

Build a railway company, and make money by transporting people and goods. You must lay track, and build bridges This version weighs supply and demand, so you shouldn't just send passengers to the same destination, but to as many destinations as possible. You have to spend your profits to add new territory you can operate in. You can buy industries or producers and make money by getting their goods to markets. New engines become available according to the date, and you can upgrade to diesel or electric trains. The game has depth, replayability and accomplishes the 'fun factor' The game is just a a tonne of fun
Scenarios have interesting and challenging victory conditions and award bronze, silver or gold depending on how well you can do.
Does not work in Windows 8, sadly. I love Railroad Tycoon more than I care about anytihng in Windows 8. I wish I could go back to 7 for Railroad Tycoon 2, I would totally do it.

reviewText:
Mean Mr. Mustard's short Railroad Tycoon II Platinum review

1) Essential - buy it NOW
2) Recommended - buy it on sale 3) Avoid

Time to complete – 25 hours to finish all campaign scenarios
Played multiplayer? N/A
Worth revisiting? No, although there are lots of optional scenarios and higher medals to earn, I didn't find the core gameplay appealing enough

Best part – Creating a nice, efficient rail system hauling cargo from raw material to final product and selling it all at the end of the line for a tidy profit
Worst part – Stock market system is very boring and unfortunately necessary on some scenarios

reviewText:
My only dissapointment with this game is that having played the original game on my CMD64 its clear that the developer has decided to 'dumb-down' the network management aspects of the game.

In the original game the player was required to design and manage their rail network and by providing signalling solutions at every network junction.  This meant that the player had much more contol over the flow of traffic, and was not assisted by the 'ghost train' system used in RT2 and subsequent releases.

You had to plan your schedule to avoid conflicts not just rely upon trains to lass magically through each other.  As such getting it wrong resulted in actually train crashes and loss of reputation, drop in customers, and a fall in the share price.

I miss that level of immersion in the game, and it means that TTD now has the edge as far as this type of game is concerned.

reviewText:
Very fun game.If you were into SimCity,SimFarm,SimTower and even the dreaded SimEarth you will love this game.Its very addictive to play,never gets tiring,and is easy on the eyes graphically for a old school game. Almost wish I was into tycoon sims back when this came out but glade I got it now.

Also to add...its packed full of different resources,train engines, and complex gameplay to keep the intelligence levels great for all difficulty types. You play from the early 1800s to the 1900s in the vanilla, then in the 2nd Century (its included expansion) you play from bout the 1850-2000 + or so.Game has sandbox mode that you can set when you start and a good amount of replay value.

Only nagging point I have about the game is the mechanics behind setting up your trains routes.The trains you have to put specific cars on so that they can pick up or drop off an item,problem is sometimes a place might not have what your train needs , so you would want to set the station to only give you what the station has.However doing this (despite having the cars already) puts new ones on which takes loading time. Since this game is a race against the clock and pausing can hold up lines, you understand how this can be annoying.

Other than that love the game.If you looking for a more hardcore simulator this one is not it.Its a strategy game first and fore most with sim elements.I suggest * OpenTTD (f2p)[www.openttd.org] ,* Simutrans (f2p)[www.simutrans.com], or * Transport Giant Gold Edition $9.99[www.gamersgate.com]

reviewText: I have fond memories of this game from when I was younger.  I enjoy a good strategy sandbox game and I loved this game as well as the original Railroad Tycoon when it first came out.  I'm not overly concerned about graphics so I figured this game would stand the test of time. Unfortunately in my opinion it doesn't.  What I originally remember being a fairly complex and challenging simulation turns out to be a pretty easy strategy game that gets very tedious very quickly.  Multiple times in my 12 hours of game play I started a new game on the most challenging settings hoping to get a good tough scenario.  Each time very early on all challenge was gone and i was able to build at will, buy up all real estate, and have no concerns as to the ownership of my company.  Just pick a starting place with a few decent cities near by, watch the needs of the city, and build accordingly.  Not a lot more to it than that.

reviewText: I really, really like trains. I bought the 3 pack of RR Tycoon 2 & 3 + Sid MEIERS RR. I don't recommend any of them.\n\nThis one of cource has very low graphics since it's an older game, but I can forgive that if the gameplay is good. Unfortunatly it is decent at best. No one thing to point at, just not much help ingame as to what all you can do, or what everything does, but you can figure out most of it. There was just no much that impressed me. Overall slightly more fun than SID MEIERS, which relied mostly on graphics, but still not worth my money, or yours.

reviewText:
Let me get this straight: I LOVE this game. It's an awesome title about managing trains, building new railroads, trading, stock market... seriously, it is fun.

Then why don't I give a reccomendation?

This game is hardlocked to 800 x 600. And full screen. You cannot get out of fullscreen mode, which is REALLY a shame.

I doubt that the bug will ever be fixed (Because it says you need to have a resolution of 1024 x 728 or higher to play in windowed mode, but that doesn't work), but as soon as the bug is fixed, I will change my review.

reviewText:
I played this game quite a bit in spite of it's many flaws.  It has improvements over the great original Railroad Tycoon, it's more realistic, there's more stuff to do, they've of course improved the graphics in the intervening the years but I don't know...it's just not fun.

I haven't played this game in some time so can't go into many details.  One thing I do remember being annoyed with is that there's a limit to how many computer players you can have on each map.  There's no reason for this.  It's not a memory issue.  On some maps you can have 32 players (or something) but on others, you can only have two.  There's no rhyme or reason.  It's not really related to map size or anything like this.  Also, on the maps with 32 or whatever players, more than half of those players NEVER BUILD ANYTHING.  They just put all of their money in the stock market trying to get rich that way.  Kind of stupid.

Anyway, hopefully they've made better railroad-building simulation games since this.  Don't bother looking at Railroad Tycoon 3 or Sid Meier's Railroads, though.  They're total crap.

Pwninator score: 5/10

reviewText: Absolutely amazing
Fantastically fun train simulator.  From a time when games couldn't rely on graphics alone to get ratings.  They had to be solid games.

My all time favourite RTS. Aging graphices don't deter from the fun but show that they could keep the same mechanics and update the graphics. Much fun to be had and many, many hours can be wasted, erm spent on this entertaining game.

Have enjoyed playing the game for the last 3 days. There is a lot of planning and thinking not just point and click. The only major problem I have had is in the last 3 days it has shut off on me with an error about 10 times. I would get deep into the game and forget to save often and it would crash and loose hours of playing. So if this game appeals to you save soon and save often.

This game is classic. I use Windows pretty much just to play this game. The Mac version was PowerPC so it doesn't work on modern Macs. The PC version runs great in Win95 compatibility mode in XP and Windows 7. I was not able to play this in Windows 8 Dev Ed.\n\n** update - released version of Windows 8 works great with this **
This is one of those games that I played as a kid and now suffer from a heavy nostalgia. Great game at a good price. If you like this game, Railroad Tycoon III is a good modern upgrade.
Feels real and visceral, very engaging. Theming is consistent and had great depth. 10/10, Would Recommend.

Got this in a 3 pack with Transport Tycoon and Railroad Tycoon one when i was a kid.

This game is well worth buying, still good even tho its old, graphics still look ok and its fun to play.
One of the Best Games Ever .. Teaches you how ther us industrial base grew..and why it grew in certain areas.  Runs fine on windows 7 32 and 64 bit.
Good for simsters. Seems to work with Win7, regarding to short test.

Build railroads, invest in the stock market and become RICH, VERY RICH!
This game is great, I played it long ago, and when I saw that it was published on steam, I bought again and got back to it.
Although quite old, the game still runs fine on Windows 7.
I only had to switch to the power saving graphics card to play it smoothly. With the performance graphics card the game is playble but the videos don't show and at times you have to unlock it with mouse clicks.
There are two campaigns and a number of scenarios, ranging from the pionnering days of the railroad in the 1800's to futuristic scenarios in 2050. There are scenarios for all continents (even Antartica!) and lots of countries.
But the real goal of the game is to become rich, very rich, beyond your wildest dreams!
You can do that investing on the stock market, but take care because you can also endup penniless! In the hard levels there is cut-throat competition and the AI can make you sweat.
I liked this game better than its successors (Railroad Tycoon 3 and Sid Meier's Railroads), even if the graphics are not as good, but the game is more balanced, RRT3 is to complex and SMRR is to simple.

reviewText: How come this is still so entertaining? And how come the computer is so much better at it than I am? =)

Got this game when it was first relased in the late 1990s. Came back to it on Steam and remembered why I liked it so much to begin with. Lots to do and lots to learn while the same scenarios will play out differently each time thanks to radomized map resources and random events.

There is much strategy to had - certain resources require other resources to make them even more successful (bring grain to a cattle farm and then send the cattle bounty to the slaughterhouse. From there, food is generated that you can send on to a city demanding it. There's nothing like seeing the massive payday of a cross-country haul reach its destination. Or stay out of commodities and simply set up a passenger/mail route between to major hubs.

Different cities/towns require different resources. Routes will vary as you pass through mountains and over rivers as will cost to build your track network and bridges. Your opponents will do what it takes to bring you down, including set up profitable routes in your backyard, buy stock in your company, or buy local businesses that you helped to become lucrative - beat them to the punch and buy those steel mills, factories, and cattle farms before they do. Buy stock in your company or a competitor's company. Deal with economic swings, advancing train technologies, and the judgement of your Board of Directors - it's all here.

The graphics are surely dated by 2010s standards but I can look beyond that limitation to recapture the fun I had with this classic title - even now I get lost in this title for hours. Of all of the strategic railroad sims out there currently (in 2015), I still feel that RRT2 is the best of the pack.

ENG:

One of the best strategy games I've ever played, if you like Civilization, SimCity, or OpenTTD building games like this too from the game. Testimonial!

The game runs on Windows 7 64-bit!

FIN:

Yksi parhaita strategia peleistä, koskaan mitä olen pelannut, jos pidät civilization, OpenTTD tai SimCity rakentamispeleistä pidät tästäkin pelistä. Suositteluni!

Peli toimii Windows 7 64-bit!!!

Blast from the past, circa 1998! This is truly one of my favorite PC games of all time. I’m happy to see it works great on my Win 7 x64 system. As far as the game itself, it’s a plain and simple railroad manager with dated graphics and horrible sound (as compared to current games). However, the gameplay is fun and it can be a challenge at times not to go bankrupt. What I've always liked about this game, was the ability to customize it. You can customize your in game character by typing in a new name and selecting a new portrait. You can customize your company by changing your logo, renaming it, and by renaming your trains & the cities/towns in which they serve. The game also sports a map/scenario editor for further customizations. As far as the tycoon" aspect goes
date: the gameplay allows for the issuance of stocks & bonds
voteText: and instigating mergers and hostile takeovers. This game was one of the best - if not the best
helpfulPercent: in the Tycoon series back in the day. In my opinion
votesHelpful: it still is today!\n\nRecommended +10 for nostalgia

reviewText: It's probably the best semi-modern railroad tycoon-type game. It lacks for me, though, the sheer joy of the first one. While the graphics and interface are crude by today's standards, your company's actions had real impacts in the game world, and that is something I don't always see in this one.  It also annoys me in the campaign that I meet certain requirements (like connecting New York to Chicago), but the game chooses not to recognize it.  Ugh.

TL;DR: This is one of my favorite games for all time. It is definitely worth checking out even today.

Where to begin with Railroad Tycoon II?

I could start with both the campaigns. The Platinum edition has two campaigns: The Original" Railroad Tycoon II campaign and the Second Century campaign.  Both cover a wide swath of history and geography
date: ranging from building the Trans-Siberian Railway to the introduction of railroads in the United States. While some of the scenarios in these campaigns are just simple train-routing puzzles
recommended: most of the campaign scenarios are quite meaty
hoursPlayed: taking a good half-hour to two hours to complete.\n\nI could mention the vast number of maps that this package includes. In addition to the campaign
voteText: the Platinum edition includes 50 other maps of varying quality and a map editor if you're interested in making more. Like the campaign
helpfulPercent: these can range in playtime from a half hour to several hours per map. However
votesHelpful: since this is an older game
votesTotal: I'm not sure how many other folks are making new maps for this game these days.\n\nI could mention the replay value of all of those maps. The game has a semi-random distribution of industries at every map start
votesFunny: which makes each play-though subtly different.\n\nI could mention the nearly two hours of blues music that is the game's soundtrack
commentsCount: or the attention to detail in the game's artwork. While it is stuck in isometric view
column16: the game's graphics don't feel particularly dated to me. The only quibbles I've got is the lack of support for wide-screen resolutions (which didn't really exist when it was made).\n\nBut
column18: I think the core gameplay as a logistics puzzle and business game is Railroad Tycoon II's strongest element. The gameplay is truly 'easy to learn
column19: difficult to master'. The idea of "Deliver one iron
column20: one coal to a steel mill
column21: then take that steel to a Tool and Die factory which produces one goods to take to a town" is simple
column24: is a real challenge. The player gets all sorts of interesting decisions along the way: From where to route track to how to finance the whole operation to what locomotive to choose."

Brilliant game, and runs fine on my windows Vista laptop. The game basically has you building a railway empire in a range of different settings, scenarios and timelines. There are a good variety of trains and rolling stock and the interface is good and easy to understand. The game seems to run stable for me and although at the time of writing I have not long had this game on steam I have had it in disk form in the past and have played many afternoons/evenings on this game. Very addictive and extremely fun.

Almost 20 years on, it's still the best of the best. It's not easy and some of the missions can be a little unintuitive but in terms of depth it's still got what it takes. Oddly charming visuals and sound, too. For those into history and geography there's a lot of great touches.

They just don't make in depth tycoon games like this anymore and it's a real shame. If you like games with deep management simulation, this game is for you! (If you can get over the fact that it is an old game) I recommend this more than Railroad Tycoon 3 for modern gamers because the appearance and interface are much sharper than its sequel. One of the more interesting aspects of this game (that many don't like) is that it focuses on your personal wealth as manager as well as the company wealth. Again, this is more of a management sim than a transport sim, and from the management standpoint this is a very unique aspect of this game that I find enjoyable. (Yet another aspect to manage)

Pros:
In depth economy (issue stocks/bonds, buy up your competitors, buy the industries, etc)
Industries are randomly generated inside map regions, makes gameplay less repetitive
Pay your competitors to use their rails
Stations have various addons to improve revenue and maintain trains
Cities grow as you supply them, and new industries appear

Cons:
Old (It is 2D, the interface was designed with efficiency in mind, but it is a later 2D game)
No mods (Such a shame)
AI do become repetitive after many, many hours of gameplay (a mod would be nice)

reviewText: Best Evar.

A fun train simulation game where you compete against other railroad companies in a race to connect the most cities with each other and the resources they need in order to grow while turning a profit for yourself. If you enjoy competitive tycoon gaming then you'll love this game. While it does have a multiplayer mode no one actually bothers anymore, so don't expect to get to play against humans. Trust me though the computers can give you a run for your money. You can normally pick this game up for around 5 dollars and I've personally wasted over 50 hours on it probably so well worth it in my opinion.

Grapics show their age, but they aren't bad. It doesn't take long to understand (save the stock market and its intricacies, ugh). If you aren't careful, you'll miss any immenent appointments, that's for sure; this game will keep you hooked for hours if this is your kind of game. It runs very, very fast, even on a puny rig like mine. Highly recommended if you like trains and the likes.
Buy the Railroad Tycoon Collection, it really is the best of this awesome series. Heck, I can even run this game on a potato. So good!\n\nIsambard Kingdom Brunel/10

YES! One of my favorite games from Win 98 is back! I had a blast on this thing back when I was single digits. Now I get to enjoy it once more. Theres something about tycoon games from the 90's that were EXCELLENT, compared to the boring ones made these days if theyre even made at all. I just wish you could start out with some fast trains :) Oh well. Brings back the nostalgia and keeps you focused.
Absolutely love this old game. It is very complex and has a lot of gameplay. Too many new games are all glitter and no depth. Beauty is only skin deep.
Undoubtably THE" best strategy/sim game I've played in my life. The business models re-playability is so good I still enjoy it almost 20 years later."

Brilliant game, and runs fine on my windows Vista laptop. The game basically has you building a railway empire in a range of different settings, scenarios and timelines. There are a good variety of trains and rolling stock and the interface is good and easy to understand. The game seems to run stable for me and although at the time of writing I have not long had this game on steam I have had it in disk form in the past and have played many afternoons/evenings on this game. Very addictive and extremely fun.
Must have if you love the genre, I owned this game for such a long time and I still go back to it.\nMust have been 16 years since I first played it :-p

The game that came out prior to this one, Railroads!, has since been given a mighty makeover and is by far the better game.  This one simply reflects the era in which it was created, when people still used Windows 3.1, and the game engine consisted of square tiles and sprites.  This one stutters quite badly, even on high spec systems, and a lack of options means you can't turn off the really annoying music.  It's like a demo" version of Railroads!  Animations are terrible
date: with trains jacknifing on single tracks
recommended: and the control GUI takes up way too much oif the screen (a common problem in those days).  A shame Sid Meier's organisation didn't makeover this one too while they were at it.  It doesn't look like an update is coming anytime soon.  Go for Railroads! instead."

reviewText: great game but where is the manual and what are the keyboard controls for this game

Almost 20 years on, it's still the best of the best. It's not easy and some of the missions can be a little unintuitive but in terms of depth it's still got what it takes. Oddly charming visuals and sound, too. For those into history and geography there's a lot of great touches.

They just don't make in depth tycoon games like this anymore and it's a real shame. If you like games with deep management simulation, this game is for you! (If you can get over the fact that it is an old game) I recommend this more than Railroad Tycoon 3 for modern gamers because the appearance and interface are much sharper than its sequel. One of the more interesting aspects of this game (that many don't like) is that it focuses on your personal wealth as manager as well as the company wealth. Again, this is more of a management sim than a transport sim, and from the management standpoint this is a very unique aspect of this game that I find enjoyable. (Yet another aspect to manage)

Pros:
In depth economy (issue stocks/bonds, buy up your competitors, buy the industries, etc)
Industries are randomly generated inside map regions, makes gameplay less repetitive
Pay your competitors to use their rails
Stations have various addons to improve revenue and maintain trains
Cities grow as you supply them, and new industries appear

Cons:
Old (It is 2D, the interface was designed with efficiency in mind, but it is a later 2D game)
No mods (Such a shame)
AI do become repetitive after many, many hours of gameplay (a mod would be nice)

This is a brilliant game - didn't play it at release but have put in 50-60 hours over the last 18 months.

Positives
- Good intuitive interface
- Nice graphics for the period
- Satisfying gameplay, reasonable level of finance management avaiable
- GREAT soundtrack!  One of the standout features, really suits the character of the game

Negatives
- Not really many micro management interaction available, i.e. no ability to set prices/rates.
- Limited options for macro management and huge scale of some of the maps make it difficult to keep an eye on     everything.   For example, you can assign a single manager to your railroad but they do not assist in day to day running and only attract discounts for running costs etc.
Would be nice if it didn't crash every 5 minutes.
Loved this game when I was little, glad they brought it on steam.

This game is friggin old. 18 years old, to be precise. So why is it still better than any of the modern games such as Railroad Tycoon 3 and Sid Meier's Railroads? Maybe it's because I like the look and feel of games of the late 90s. Maybe it's just becasue the graphics are not overwhelming, the game is excellently balanced, and the sandbox nature makes it eternally replayable.

I do wish I could find more maps and mods for this game. I know there are some, but it doesn't feel like they're enough.

They should make a new version of the game, with HD graphics, fixed bugs and annoyances, and little. Stop making new Railroad Tycoons and simply perfect this one!

I like a good commercial simulation game. Set up supply chains, deliver products, make money!

Railroad Tycoon 2 does that, and does a pretty good job of it.

Things I like
Flexibility: you get to decide where your tracks go, how you load the trains and even though you can program routes to do what you want over and over, you can micromanage if you want.
Historical Trains: The game tells a bit about the historical context behind the different scenerios, which is fun. The trains are based on actual trains that were used. The cargos that you can carry evolve as the years pass (Oil doesn't become an useful cargo until after a certain year, for example)
Worldwide settings: With scenerios set all over the world, any place that trains were important you get to try your hand at setting up your own empire.

Things that bothered me
I never really got the hang of the mechanic for driving your opponents out of business by buying them, or investing in them. Maybe I just wasn't paying close enough attention or something, but it seemed really tough to figure out what to buy, and when, and whether doing so would have the desired outcome.
Sometimes putting a track down at just the place you want can be fiddly... that's probably unavoidable, but I found myself spending hours on pause just sorting out the best way to lay track between Germany and Italy, and I haven't yet figured out how to get track laid effectively in Japan.

Overall, this game was totally worth it for me. I have easily gotten my money's worth.
Train/10, it's a real train wreck

This game still stands up as a great in the strategy genre. These days people are spoon-fed victories and achievements. This game can, at times, be impossible to achieve Gold if you don't get the right start. It makes it actually worth playing for the Gold.\n\nWorks great on Win8.1 and 10 in my experience. Thanks for bringing it back!

I've played this game off and on for years dating back to the DOS version that put it on the map.  Smooth gameplay and a complex editor makes creating your own scenarios and playing them a joy.  If you like the original versions you will enjoy this one even more.
